Hadean Eon – the earliest period of Earth's history, spanning from the planet's formation approximately 4.56 billion years ago until the emergence of stable tectonic plates around 4.0 billion years ago.
The landscape of the Early Hadean was extremely hostile, resembling a hellish environment. The surface was dominated by widespread volcanic activity, molten rock, and frequent bombardment by meteorites and comets.
The first 100 million years were far too inhospitable for any form of life, with surface temperatures reaching around 230 degrees Celsius—and in the earliest stages, even exceeding 2000 degrees Celsius. Atmospheric pressure was estimated to be about 27 times higher than today. While Earth possessed a primitive atmosphere, it was repeatedly stripped away by intense collisions with other celestial bodies.
Around 4.4 billion years ago, the planet began to cool, as evidenced by zircon crystals, which suggest the presence of liquid water during this period. The end of the Hadean Eon is marked by the stabilization of Earth's crust, the formation of early oceans, and the beginnings of continental crust.

There is no definitive proof that life could have existed in such a harsh environment. However, 4.1-billion-year-old graphite deposits found in Western Australia contain carbon isotopes that suggest possible biological origins, indicating that conditions for life may have been sustainable earlier than previously thought. Some scientists hypothesize that life may have emerged multiple times during the Hadean Eon, only to be repeatedly annihilated by catastrophic asteroid impacts and extreme volcanic activity. Additionally, carbon-rich meteorites, which delivered organic molecules to early Earth, support the idea that the building blocks of life may have originated in space.

The Archean Eon – the second eon in Earth\'s history – spans from approximately 4.0 billion years ago, when the first tectonic plates began to form, to around 2.5 billion years ago, just before the Great Oxidation Event.\nAt the beginning of this eon, Earth\'s temperature was 2–3 times higher than today. This was primarily due to a high concentration of greenhouse gases (dozens of times higher than today) and residual heat from planetary accretion and core formation.\nDuring this period, the Sun\'s luminosity was about 70–75% of its present level, leading to a \"faint young Sun paradox\", which was mitigated by the greenhouse effect. By the end of the Archean, Earth\'s tectonic activity had evolved into a more modern-like system, and vast oceans of liquid water covered much of the planet, providing the conditions for the emergence of early microbial life.

Around 4.0 billion years ago, the planets of our solar system, including Earth, experienced intense bombardment by large cosmic bodies for approximately 200 million years. This period, known as the Late Heavy Bombardment (LHB), is evidenced by lunar samples collected by Apollo astronauts, which contain high-impact melt formations.
Extrapolating lunar cratering rates to Earth at this time suggests that the planet would have experienced:
1. Approximately 22,000 craters with diameters greater than 20 km.
2. Around 40 craters with diameters exceeding 1,000 km.
3. Several craters with diameters close to 5,000 km.
The prevailing hypothesis for this bombardment is that the giant planets—such as Jupiter, Saturn, and Neptune—underwent orbital migration. This gravitational disturbance scattered objects from the asteroid and/or Kuiper belts into eccentric orbits, increasing the impact rate on the inner planets. This event may have delayed the emergence of life during the Early Archean by creating a hostile surface environment through frequent, high-energy impacts.

Unlike in the Hadean, the presence of life during the Archean is well established, though the exact timing of its emergence remains debated.
The earliest solid evidence of life comes from 3.48-billion-year-old stromatolites found in Australia and 3.77–4.28-billion-year-old microfossils discovered in Canadian rocks. Additionally, 3.85-billion-year-old isotopic signatures in Greenland suggest biological activity, though their interpretation is contested.
Banded iron formations (BIFs) also date back to this period. While some argue that their formation required oxygen from early photosynthetic microbes, others suggest alternative abiotic processes could have played a role.
Possible early prokaryotes have been identified in Canadian rocks at least 3.77 billion years old, and lipid biomarker analysis suggests that the first eukaryotes may have emerged by the late Archean, around 2.7 billion years ago.

The Proterozoic Eon – the third major eon in Earth\'s history, spanning from approximately 2.5 billion to 541 million years ago, just before the widespread emergence of complex life. Key events of this eon include the transition to an oxygen-rich atmosphere during the Great Oxidation Event, multiple global glaciations (such as those associated with the Snowball Earth hypothesis during the Huronian, Sturtian, and Marinoan glaciations), and the evolution of early multicellular eukaryotic organisms, including soft-bodied life forms like those of the Ediacaran biota.\nThis is a hypothetical reconstruction of a Snowball Earth scenario during the Huronian and Cryogenian glaciations.

The Great Oxidation Event was the biologically induced rise of oxygen in Earth's atmosphere, occurring around 2.4 to 2.1 billion years ago. The widely accepted hypothesis states that the primary driver of this event was the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis in cyanobacteria.
Before this event, any free oxygen produced was rapidly consumed by chemical reactions with dissolved iron or organic matter. However, once these oxygen sinks became saturated, excess oxygen began accumulating in the atmosphere.
Free oxygen is toxic to obligate anaerobic organisms, leading to a major extinction event. Additionally, atmospheric oxygen reacted with methane, a potent greenhouse gas, significantly lowering its concentration. This process likely triggered the Huronian glaciation, which lasted approximately 300 million years (from ~2.4 to ~2.1 billion years ago).
These profound changes in Earth's atmospheric and chemical cycles created new evolutionary pressures and opportunities. Life adapted first to tolerate and then to harness atmospheric oxygen, leading to the development of aerobic respiration. This metabolic breakthrough vastly increased the available energy supply, enabling the evolution of more complex, multicellular organisms.

The Proterozoic Eon marks a crucial transition in the evolution of life, from simple unicellular organisms to more complex forms. During the Great Oxidation Event, many anaerobic organisms declined due to oxygen toxicity, while oxygen-tolerant and aerobic life forms, including early eukaryotic protists and bacteria, proliferated. By the mid-Proterozoic, stromatolites—microbial reef-like structures built by cyanobacteria—reached their peak diversity. During this time, the ancestors of fungi diverged from the ancestors of animals, marking an important evolutionary split within eukaryotes. By the Ediacaran Period (635–541 million years ago), the first complex, soft-bodied multicellular organisms had appeared, including members of the enigmatic Ediacaran biota, which represent some of the earliest known macroscopic life forms.

The Cambrian Period was the first geological period of the Paleozoic Era and marked a profound transformation in life on Earth. Before the Cambrian, most living organisms were microscopic and relatively simple. However, the Cambrian saw an unprecedented diversification of life in an event known as the Cambrian Explosion. During this time, many major animal phyla first appeared in the fossil record, and complex ecosystems emerged.\nThe great glaciers of the late Proterozoic Eon had long melted, leading to high sea levels that flooded vast areas of continents with warm, shallow seas—an ideal environment for marine life. The Earth was generally cool during the Early Cambrian, likely due to the supercontinent Gondwana covering the South Pole, which disrupted polar ocean currents. However, global temperatures were still around 7°C higher than today. While polar ice caps and glaciations may have existed, the climate gradually warmed toward the end of the period. Glaciers retreated, sea levels rose dramatically, and this warming trend continued into the Ordovician Period.

The Cambrian Explosion was a relatively brief evolutionary event, during which approximately 63% of all biological classes and most of the major modern animal phyla first appeared. This period saw the emergence of complex ecosystems, with the development of burrowing behaviors and the widespread diversification of skeletonized animals, which were previously absent or rare.
Possible causes of this evolutionary event:
1. Increased atmospheric oxygen levels, which supported larger and more complex organisms.
2. The formation of an ozone layer, reducing the harmful effects of ultraviolet (UV) radiation and enabling life to thrive in shallower waters.
3. The Snowball Earth events during the late Proterozoic, which led to mass extinctions and opened up ecological niches for new life forms.
4. Higher calcium concentrations in Cambrian seawater, allowing marine organisms to develop skeletons, shells, and other hard body structures.
5. Developmental changes, including the evolution of Hox genes, which played a key role in organizing body plans and enabling more complex organisms to form.
6. Changes in the food web, leading to coevolution and predator-prey “arms races” that drove anatomical and behavioral innovations.
The Cambrian was also a time of evolutionary experimentation, resulting in many bizarre and unique body plans, some of which have no modern descendants.

Most animal life during the Cambrian was aquatic. Arthropods were by far the most dominant animals in the ocean, with trilobites being particularly abundant. This period also saw the emergence of many new mineralized organisms, as well as the first widespread burrowing animals, which played a key role in reshaping seafloor ecosystems. However, unlike in modern times, most animals lived on or near the sea floor, with very few swimming or pelagic species.

The Ordovician is the second of six periods of the Paleozoic Era. During this period, ancient oceans separated the largely barren continents of Laurentia, Baltica, Siberia, and the supercontinent Gondwana. The Ordovician saw a great diversification of marine life, including the rise of early corals, cephalopods, and the first jawless fish. However, the period ended with one of the most severe ice ages in Earth’s history, leading to the second-largest mass extinction, which wiped out around 85% of marine species. Ice sheets covered much of the southern region of Gondwana, dramatically altering global sea levels and climate.

The Ordovician period is notable for the Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event (GOBE), a time of rapid biological diversification that replaced the distinctive Cambrian fauna with a Paleozoic fauna rich in suspension feeders and pelagic animals. This event followed the Cambrian-Ordovician extinction, which was likely caused by a sudden glaciation and a depletion of available oxygen in the oceans.\nThe primary driver of the Ordovician radiation was a major shift in paleogeography. Due to high sea levels, continents became highly fragmented into distinct marine provinces, fostering regional biodiversity. Intense orogeny (mountain-building events), along with increased erosion, contributed to high ecosystem productivity by delivering abundant nutrients into the oceans.\nWhile the Cambrian Explosion was crucial in establishing most modern animal phyla, the GOBE can be seen as the event that diversified these phyla into modern classes and lower-level taxa, significantly shaping marine ecosystems that would persist for millions of years.

Life during the Ordovician continued to flourish, with an explosion of marine biodiversity, including the rise of the first coral reefs, trilobites, brachiopods, mollusks, and the first true vertebrates—jawless fish. However, the period ended with a catastrophic mass extinction at the boundary with the Silurian. This extinction was primarily driven by severe global cooling, glaciation, and associated sea-level changes. Despite this, the fauna that emerged and thrived during the Ordovician laid the foundation for marine ecosystems throughout the remainder of the Paleozoic Era.

The Silurian is a relatively short geological period, lasting approximately 24 to 28 million years. During this time, Laurentia collided with Baltica, closing the northern branch of the Iapetus Ocean and forming the "Old Red Sandstone" continent. Coral reefs thrived, becoming more widespread and diverse, and the first vascular land plants began to colonize the previously barren continents, marking a significant evolutionary step in the history of life on land.

The evolutionary appearance of vascular plants dramatically altered Earth's environment, paving the way for animal life on land and fundamentally changing Earth's atmosphere. Interestingly, plant evolution progressed much faster than animal evolution: during the Late Silurian, plants were structurally simple and small, but by the end of the Devonian (approximately 46 million years later), almost all present-day plant lineages (except flowering plants) had emerged.
One possible explanation is that adapting to terrestrial life posed a greater challenge for plants than for animals. At the level of the individual organism, all plants (except parasitic ones) must perform four essential functions to grow and survive:
1. Intercept sunlight.
2. Exchange atmospheric gases with the environment.
3. Acquire, transport, and conserve water.
4. Cope with external mechanical forces.
These tasks are interdependent and often conflict with one another. For example: a) Increasing surface area to capture more sunlight and facilitate gas exchange can reduce water conservation. b) Positioning leaves horizontally to maximize light interception increases mechanical stress.
Aquatic environments are relatively uniform and stable, while terrestrial environments are affected by wind, temperature changes, unpredictable precipitation, and varying sunlight. Adapting to diverse terrestrial conditions required innovative solutions for each of the basic functions, leading to significant diversification in plant body forms.
Additionally, greater exposure to ultraviolet light above the wate's surface likely caused more mutations, accelerating evolutionary changes. However, the theory of plant fitness—how well plants adapted to the challenges of terrestrial life—best explains the rapid evolution of land plants.

Multicellular life began to appear on land in the form of small, bryophyte-like and early vascular plants that grew near lakes, streams, and coastlines. The Silurian period also marked the first appearance of arthropods on land, including primitive millipedes and arachnids. However, terrestrial life would not significantly diversify or impact the landscape until the Devonian period.\nA major evolutionary milestone during the Silurian was the diversification of bony fishes (Osteichthyes), which began to dominate marine ecosystems. This diversification laid the foundation for the evolution of many modern fish lineages.

The Devonian is the fourth of the six periods of the Paleozoic era. It was a relatively warm period, though occasionally disrupted by glaciations. The climate was generally arid, particularly near the equator. During this time, the Early Paleozoic oceans were gradually closing, leading to the formation of a “pre-Pangea” supercontinent. This continental configuration allowed fish to migrate from the southern hemisphere continents to North America and Europe. For the first time, extensive forests appeared in the equatorial regions of what is now Arctic Canada. The period concluded with the Late Devonian extinction, which resulted in the loss of about 50% of all genera, significantly impacting marine life, including many fish and reef-building organisms.

The Late Devonian extinction was one of the five major extinction events in Earth's history. Rather than being a single event, it consisted of a series of two major crises known as the Kellwasser and Hangenberg events. It is estimated that around 75% of all animal species disappeared during this time. The extinction primarily affected marine life, severely impacting groups such as brachiopods, trilobites, and reef-building organisms, which almost completely collapsed. Major fish groups like Placodermi, Heterostraci, and Anaspida were completely wiped out. The extinction event destroyed approximately 97% of all vertebrate species, with only smaller forms surviving. In the aftermath, no sharks larger than a meter and almost no fishes or tetrapods larger than 10 centimeters remained, and it would take around 10 million years before they began to increase in size again. However, despite its catastrophic impact, the Late Devonian extinction crucially paved the way for the evolution of modern vertebrate fauna, including actinopterygians (ray-finned fishes), chondrichthyans (cartilaginous fishes), and tetrapods.
The crash in biodiversity during the Late Devonian was more drastic than the famous mass extinction event at the end of the Cretaceous.
The causes of this extinction event remain uncertain. Some proposed explanations include:
1. An asteroid impact.
2. Evolutionary changes in plants, particularly the development of root systems, which led to massive water eutrophication and subsequent anoxia.
3. A reduction in atmospheric carbon dioxide, causing global cooling.
4. Increased magmatism and volcanic activity.

Free-sporing vascular plants began to spread across dry land during the Devonian period, covering the continents with extensive forests. By the Middle Devonian, several groups of plants had evolved leaves and true roots, marking significant advancements in plant evolution. Groups such as lycophytes, equisetophytes, and pteridophytes diversified, forming the first complex terrestrial ecosystems.\nFish achieved remarkable diversity during this time, earning the Devonian the nickname “Age of Fish”. Placoderms, armored prehistoric fish, were the most dominant group. The ancestors of tetrapods, particularly lobe-finned fish, began to adapt to walking on land, as their robust pectoral and pelvic fins gradually evolved into legs. These transitional species paved the way for the later evolution of amphibians.\nThe first ammonites (a group of molluscs) appeared, marking an important diversification of marine life. Trilobites and large coral reef systems remained common, with one notable now-dry barrier reef, located in what is now the Kimberley Basin of Northwest Australia, once extending approximately a thousand kilometers.

The name "Carboniferous" means “coal-bearing,” referring to the extensive coal deposits formed during this period. In the Early Carboniferous, the Paleozoic oceans between Euramerica and Gondwana began to close, giving rise to mountain ranges such as the Appalachians and the Variscans. A large ice cap developed over the South Pole, while lush, tropical coal swamps near the Equator supported the evolution of four-legged vertebrates (tetrapods) and the first winged insects.

The Carboniferous Rainforest Collapse was a significant ecological event that occurred around 305 million years ago. It disrupted the vast coal forests that once covered the equatorial region, fragmenting them into isolated patches. This fragmentation led to dwarfism and the eventual extinction of many plant and animal species.
The collapse resulted in the extinction of dominant lycopsid trees and a shift toward ecosystems dominated by more opportunistic plants like tree ferns. Before the event, animal species were distributed widely across the forests, but afterward, each isolated “island” of rainforest developed its own unique mix of species—this process is known as endemism.
Oxygen levels reached a record high of approximately 32.5% during the Carboniferous, allowing enormous arthropods like Meganeura (a giant dragonfly-like insect) and Arthropleura (a giant millipede-like arthropod) to thrive. However, following the rainforest collapse, oxygen levels declined, leading to the extinction of many of these giants. The increasingly arid climate also caused a mass decline in amphibian diversity, opening ecological space for reptiles to diversify—organisms better suited to dry environments.
Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the collapse, with the most widely accepted being climate aridification and increased volcanic activity.
This event also played a role in the formation of large coal deposits. During the Carboniferous, extensive swamp forests prevented the full decomposition of dead plant material. At the time, few animals or microbes had evolved enzymes to break down tough substances like phenolic lignin and waxy suberin. Fungi capable of decomposing these materials appeared only toward the end of the period, which is one reason why massive coal formation is largely limited to the Carboniferous.

The Carboniferous is renowned for its vast tropical rainforests dominated by towering plants like Lepidodendron, Sigillaria, and Calamites—some of the largest and most extensive forests in Earth’s history. Giant arthropods and insects thrived during this time, aided by high atmospheric oxygen levels and the absence of effective predators. Terrestrial vertebrates became increasingly abundant: amphibians diversified greatly, and following the Carboniferous Rainforest Collapse, reptiles began to flourish due to their better adaptation to drier environments.

The Permian was the final period of the Paleozoic Era, it ended with the most extensive mass extinction in Earth’s history, wiping out approximately 90% of marine species and 70% of terrestrial species. During this time, most of the world\'s landmasses were joined into two large continents—Pangaea and Siberia—surrounded by a vast global ocean called Panthalassa. Western Pangaea was dominated by arid deserts, while reptiles, including early ancestors of mammals, diversified and spread widely across the supercontinent.

The Permian and the entire Paleozoic Era ended 252 million years ago with the most severe mass extinction in Earth's history. The Permian-Triassic extinction event, also known as the Great Dying, wiped out about 95% of all marine species and 70% of all terrestrial species.
Marine environments were hit particularly hard. Entire groups such as acanthodians (spiny sharks), sea scorpions, trilobites (already in decline), fusulinids, and Tabulata and Rugosa corals became completely extinct. Shelled marine animals were severely affected—96% of brachiopod species, 97% of ammonites, 59% of bivalves, and 98% of gastropods perished.
Terrestrial ecosystems also suffered enormously. Most large tetrapods disappeared, and around 80% of insect species were lost. Paleozoic wet forests, once dominated by ancient plants like Sigillaria, Lepidodendron, and Gigantopteris, were devastated due to widespread aridification and intense wildfires.
Several interlinked causes contributed to this catastrophe:
1. Massive volcanic eruptions in the region now known as the Siberian Traps released enormous quantities of carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide. These gases drastically altered atmospheric chemistry. Methane reacted with atmospheric oxygen, reducing oxygen levels from 30% to around 13%. The ozone layer was damaged, exposing the surface to harmful ultraviolet radiation. This led to a rapid increase in global temperatures—by as much as 8°C.
2. Oceans became dangerously deoxygenated. Warmer temperatures reduced oxygen absorption, and toxic gases led to acidification. Acidic water dissolved the calcium carbonate shells of mollusks and corals, leading to their mass extinction. The proliferation of cyanobacteria and microbial mats further consumed what little oxygen remained, turning the seas into anoxic, acidic, nearly lifeless zones.
3. A temporary weakening of Earth's magnetic field may have allowed increased solar radiation to reach the surface, creating extreme seasonal swings with scorching summers followed by bitterly cold winters.
The devastation was so profound that ecosystems took over 30 million years to recover their former diversity—not until the Middle Triassic. The extinction selectively eliminated dominant Paleozoic life forms, erasing 79% of their families, while only 27% of the lineages that would come to thrive in the Mesozoic were affected.

The Permian began with Carboniferous-era plant life still thriving. In the Middle Permian, a major shift in vegetation occurred: swamp-loving lycopod trees such as Lepidodendron and Sigillaria were gradually replaced by more advanced seed ferns like Glossopteris, along with early conifers, ginkgoes, and cycads.\nInsects during this time were dominated by primitive relatives of cockroaches and early dragonflies. Early Permian terrestrial ecosystems were populated by pelycosaurs (sail-backed synapsids like Dimetrodon) and large amphibians. By the Middle Permian, these groups declined and were succeeded by primitive therapsids—mammal-like reptiles. In the Late Permian, more advanced therapsids such as gorgonopsians emerged, becoming top predators.\nToward the very end of the Permian, the first archosaurs appeared—a group that would later evolve into dinosaurs, pterosaurs, and crocodiles. Also emerging in this period were the earliest cynodonts, small therapsids that would eventually give rise to mammals in the Triassic.

The Triassic began in the aftermath of the Permian-Triassic extinction event, the most severe extinction in Earth\'s history, which left the biosphere severely impoverished. Life began to recover significantly only by the middle of the Triassic period. \nDuring this time, the supercontinent Pangea was largely assembled, enabling land animals to migrate freely from the South Pole to the North Pole. Additionally, warm-water marine species spread across the vast Tethys Sea, supporting a resurgence of biodiversity in the oceans.

The nocturnal bottleneck hypothesis explains several unique traits of mammals. According to this hypothesis, mammals were primarily—or even exclusively—nocturnal for most of their early evolutionary history, beginning around 225 million years ago during the Late Triassic and continuing until the extinction of the dinosaurs around 65 million years ago. While some mammal groups later adapted to daytime (diurnal) activity, the approximately 160 million years spent in nocturnal niches left a lasting legacy on their anatomy and physiology. As a result, many mammals today retain nocturnal habits.
Mammals evolved from cynodonts, a group of mammal-like reptiles with dog-like features, in the aftermath of the Permian-Triassic mass extinction. Following this extinction, archosaurian reptiles—including ancestors of crocodiles and dinosaurs—rapidly diversified and came to dominate most ecological roles. This competition pushed the larger cynodonts toward extinction, leaving only smaller, more adaptable forms.
These surviving cynodonts likely occupied nocturnal, insect-eating niches with less competition from the dominant, diurnal dinosaurs. Over time, they evolved into early mammals—small-bodied, warm-blooded, and adapted to life in the undergrowth.
Even after the extinction of the dinosaurs, mammals remained small for millions of years. Although mammals now include many large species, most are still relatively small and active at night.
The nocturnal bottleneck hypothesis also offers a compelling explanation for the evolution of mammalian warm-bloodedness (endothermy): cooler nighttime temperatures and burrowing lifestyles would have favored efficient internal temperature regulation and insulation.

The Permian-Triassic extinction devastated both terrestrial and marine ecosystems. Although biodiversity began to rebound during the Triassic, early recovery stages were dominated by only a few resilient species. For example, up to 90% of large terrestrial vertebrates initially belonged to a single genus of therapsids—Lystrosaurus—highlighting the severe ecological damage and lack of biodiversity. Complex ecosystems with diverse food webs took nearly 30 million years to fully re-establish.
By the Middle Triassic, large therapsids had largely disappeared, and archosaurs—relatives of modern crocodiles, birds, and ancestors of dinosaurs—became the dominant land vertebrates. Dinosaurs began to diversify and gradually establish their dominance by the end of the period.
On land, seed plants became increasingly dominant over spore-bearing plants. In the Northern Hemisphere, conifers, ferns, and bennettitales thrived, while in the Southern Hemisphere, Glossopteris trees initially remained prominent before disappearing later in the period.
Like other geological periods, the Triassic ended with a mass extinction. This event led to the disappearance of conodonts (a group of jawless marine vertebrates), many marine reptiles and invertebrates, and some remaining large therapsids and amphibians.

The Jurassic is the second period of the Mesozoic Era, often called the Age of Reptiles. During the Middle Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea began to break apart. By the Late Jurassic, the Central Atlantic Ocean had formed as a narrow sea separating Africa from North America. Additionally, Eastern Gondwana had started to drift away from Western Gondwana. This tectonic activity helped shape the continents as we know them today and influenced global climates and ecosystems.

About 20 million years after the Permian-Triassic extinction, dinosaurs evolved from their archosaurian ancestors and began to compete with the dominant archosauromorphs and therapsids. Initially, they were not the leading terrestrial animals. However, after the Triassic-Jurassic extinction event—which eliminated many of their competitors—dinosaurs rose to dominance and filled most major ecological niches for the next 135 million years.
Two major questions remain:
1. How did some terrestrial dinosaurs grow to such massive sizes? Many sauropods, such as Argentinosaurus (estimated at over 70 tons), Mamenchisaurus, and Diplodocus, were enormous.
2. Were dinosaurs feathered and warm-blooded?
These two questions are closely related, but still not fully resolved.
The largest dinosaurs were herbivores, and large body size likely provided protection from predators. In crowded ecosystems, herbivores may have evolved toward unoccupied ecological niches—especially larger size—creating an evolutionary “arms race” toward gigantism, within the constraints of physics and environment.
Fossil evidence shows that sauropods grew at astonishing rates—up to 5,000 kg per year. Such rapid growth suggests a high metabolic rate, unlike that of modern cold-blooded animals. However, high metabolism can become a disadvantage for very large animals, as heating and cooling large volumes of tissue becomes energetically costly. Current research suggests that juvenile sauropods were likely warm-blooded, but their metabolic rate may have decreased as they matured.
Our understanding of dinosaur physiology continues to evolve. The outdated view of dinosaurs as sluggish, cold-blooded reptiles has largely been replaced by the idea that many species had active metabolisms and some form of thermoregulation. Fossil evidence from North America suggests some dinosaurs lived seasonally in cold climates. The discovery of feathered dinosaurs—including large species like Velociraptor and possibly even Tyrannosaurus rex—supports the theory that feathers were common among theropods. The only dinosaurs to survive the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction—modern birds—are both feathered and warm-blooded. This raises a compelling question: why wouldn’t many Jurassic dinosaurs share these traits?

During the Jurassic period, the dominant marine vertebrates were fish and a variety of marine reptiles, including ichthyosaurs (marine reptiles that resembled modern dolphins), plesiosaurs (long-necked, paddle-limbed swimmers), pliosaurs (a group of plesiosaurs with shorter necks and larger heads), and marine-adapted crocodilians. Numerous turtles inhabited freshwater environments such as lakes and rivers.\nThe Jurassic was a golden age for sauropods—gigantic, long-necked herbivores like Diplodocus, Brachiosaurus, and Apatosaurus. It also saw the appearance of the first avialans (early bird-like dinosaurs), including the famous Archaeopteryx, which had feathers and could likely glide or make short powered flights.\nThe arid, continental conditions that characterized the Triassic gradually gave way to a more humid and tropical climate during the Jurassic. This warmer, wetter environment allowed dense forests and lush vegetation to spread. Conifers, along with cycads, ginkgoes, and ferns, dominated the plant life.

The Cretaceous was the final period of the Mesozoic Era, ending about 66 million years ago with a massive mass extinction — famously caused by an asteroid impact that contributed to the extinction of non-avian dinosaurs. This period was characterized by a relatively warm global climate and high sea levels, which formed vast shallow inland seas.
During the Cretaceous, the South Atlantic Ocean began to open as South America and Africa drifted apart. India separated from Madagascar and moved rapidly northward toward a future collision with Eurasia — a movement that would eventually form the Himalayas. North America was still connected to Europe at times, and Australia remained attached to Antarctica.

The Cretaceous also saw the diversification of flowering plants (angiosperms), which began to transform ecosystems and food chains. Many modern insect groups appeared, co-evolving with these plants. In the oceans, large marine reptiles like mosasaurs thrived, while the skies were dominated by pterosaurs and early birds.
End of the Age of Dinosaurs

The Cretaceous Period ended with a massive extinction event, known as the Cretaceous–Paleogene (K–Pg) extinction. Numerous plant and animal species were wiped out, including all non-avian dinosaurs. With the exception of some cold-blooded species like turtles and crocodilians, no tetrapods weighing more than 25 kilograms are known to have survived. This event marked the end of both the Cretaceous Period and the entire Mesozoic Era, ushering in the Cenozoic Era that continues to this day.
What could cause such a devastating extinction? Today, there is overwhelming scientific consensus that the main cause was a massive asteroid — approximately 10 to 15 kilometers in diameter — that struck near what is now Mexico’s Yucatán Peninsula. The impact triggered global catastrophe: debris and dust ejected into the atmosphere blocked sunlight for months to years, halting photosynthesis. As a result, plant life collapsed, followed by the extinction of herbivores and then carnivores higher up the food chain.
The asteroid struck a region rich in sulfur-containing carbonate rock, releasing sulfur aerosols and causing acid rain and ocean acidification. This sharp drop in pH levels devastated marine ecosystems, wiping out many shell-forming organisms like ammonites and corals, along with the animals that fed on them. Sea surface temperatures fell by as much as 7°C, and it took hundreds of thousands of years for Earth’s climate and ecosystems to recover.
One intriguing question is why some of the dinosaurs’ close relatives, like crocodilians, survived. It is believed that their cold-blooded metabolism and ability to survive long periods without food helped them endure the harsh post-impact conditions — further evidence that non-avian dinosaurs were likely warm-blooded, at least to some extent.
The elimination of dominant Cretaceous species opened ecological niches for new life forms. This led to a remarkable period of adaptive radiation in the Paleogene. The most striking example is the rise of mammals, which quickly diversified to occupy roles previously held by dinosaurs. In a profound sense, the eventual evolution of humans may have depended on the extinction of the dinosaurs.

Flowering plants (angiosperms) first appeared during the Cretaceous, though they did not become ecologically dominant until the latter part of the period. Their evolution was closely tied to the emergence of pollinating insects, especially bees. In fact, angiosperms and insects are classic examples of coevolution — each influencing the evolution of the other. The Cretaceous also saw the first appearances of many modern leafy trees, such as figs, plane trees, and magnolias.
On land, mammals were typically small, but they were a vital part of the ecosystem. The dominant terrestrial predators remained archosaurian reptiles — especially dinosaurs, which reached their peak in diversity during this time. Pterosaurs were widespread in the Early and Middle Cretaceous, though their diversity declined later in the period for reasons that remain unclear.
Insects underwent a significant diversification during the Cretaceous, with the emergence of many modern groups including ants, termites, butterflies and moths, aphids, grasshoppers, and gall wasps.
In the oceans, rays, modern sharks, and bony fishes became increasingly common. Marine reptiles included ichthyosaurs, which thrived in the Early and Middle Cretaceous, and later plesiosaurs and mosasaurs, which rose to prominence before the end of the period.

The Paleogene is the first period of the Cenozoic Era and includes the Paleocene, Eocene, and Oligocene epochs. The end of the Paleocene (around 55 million years ago) was marked by the Paleocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), one of the most significant global warming events of the Cenozoic. This event caused rapid increases in temperature, major shifts in ecosystems, and the extinction of many deep-sea species.\nThroughout the Paleogene, Earth’s climate gradually cooled and dried, though this trend was occasionally interrupted by short-lived warming events. One major factor contributing to the cooling was the formation of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current, which thermally isolated Antarctica and significantly cooled ocean waters.\nDuring this period, the Indian subcontinent began colliding with Asia, giving rise to the Himalayan Mountains and the Tibetan Plateau. Australia, previously connected to Antarctica, started drifting northward, eventually influencing the formation of unique ecosystems like those found today.

The Paleocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM) was a period when global average temperatures were 5–8 °C warmer than today. This major climate event began around 55.5 million years ago, at the boundary between the Paleocene and Eocene epochs.
It was triggered by two massive releases of carbon into the atmosphere, each lasting approximately 1,500 years. In total, the PETM lasted about 200,000 years. The amount of carbon released during this period was more than 30 times greater than all fossil fuels burned to date and comparable to the total known fossil fuel reserves.
The likely causes of this carbon surge include the melting of methane clathrates (frozen methane on the ocean floor) and volcanic activity heating organic-rich sediments, releasing large amounts of methane.
This warming led to increased storminess in some areas (similar to today’s Caribbean and East Asia), higher aridity in tropical regions, and greater humidity near the poles. While ecosystems were severely disrupted, most species—except deep-sea foraminifera—survived by adapting or migrating. This period also saw the rise of many modern mammal groups, including early primates, hoofed mammals (ungulates), and ancestors of whales (cetaceans). There were widespread shifts in plant and animal ranges across continents.
Notably, many mammal species underwent dwarfing, likely due to higher temperatures and lower nutrient content in plants. Under elevated CO₂ levels, plants can grow faster but tend to have reduced nutritional value, which may explain why early horses shrank in size by 20–30%.
The PETM offers a valuable ancient parallel to today’s human-driven global warming, providing important insights into how Earth’s systems and species respond to rapid climate change.

Mammals underwent rapid diversification during the Paleogene period. Some evolved into large land-dwelling forms that would dominate terrestrial ecosystems, while others adapted to life in the oceans, eventually giving rise to modern whales and dolphins (cetaceans). Still others took to the trees and became early primates, the ancestors of monkeys, apes, and humans.\nBirds, already well established by the end of the Cretaceous, also experienced a major adaptive radiation. With the extinction of pterosaurs, they became the dominant flying vertebrates, spreading into a wide variety of ecological niches.\nAs the global climate cooled over the course of the Paleogene, tropical plant species became less widespread, retreating toward equatorial regions. In contrast, temperate forests and grasslands began to expand, shaping the habitats available for the evolving animal life.

The Neogene is a period that spans 20.45 million years. It is sub-divided into two epochs, the earlier Miocene and the later Pliocene. The Isthmus of Panama connected North and South America later in the Pliocene, cutting off the Atlantic Ocean from the warm ocean currents from the Pacific, and leaving only the Gulf Stream to transfer heat to the Arctic Ocean. The global climate cooled considerably over the course of the Neogene, culminating in a series of continental glaciations in the Quaternary period that follows.\n20 million years ago, Antarctica was covered by ice and the northern continents were cooling rapidly. The world has taken on a \"modern\" look, but notice that Florida and parts of Asia were under water.

During the Neogene world became much drier and cooler, culminating disaster of the Pleistocene ice ages and the harsh conditions of our own day. During this interval, the relatively uniform and stable climatic regime which had cradled the world’s ecosystems for 200 million years, since the Late Triassic, came to a comparatively quick end. The drift of the continents had sealed off the waters of the far arctic, as the northern margins of Asia and North America crowded together. The closing of the Isthmus of Panama prevented warm currents from the Pacific to the Atlantic. In the south, Antarctica, now out of contact with any other landmass, was circled by a continuous circum-polar current. Perhaps for the first time since the Ordovician, both poles were thermally isolated from the warm equatorial waters and started accumulating heavy coverings of ice. The ice sheets, in turn reflected more sunlight and lowered sea levels, further reducing temperatures and warm-water circulation.\nThe world dried out, huge deserts developed in North Africa and Central Asia. The deep forests of the continental interiors were replaced by arid plains, steppe, prairie or tundra. Many herbivorous animal species died out or were forced to change together with their predators. By the end of the period, the world became similar to what we see now.

During this period, mammals and birds continued to evolve into roughly modern forms, while other groups remained relatively unchanged. Early hominids, the ancestors of humans, appeared in Africa near the end of this period and later spread into Eurasia. Tropical plant species gave way to deciduous ones and grasslands replaced many forests. Grasses therefore greatly diversified, and herbivorous mammals evolved alongside it, creating the many grazing animals of today, such as horses and antelopes.

The Quaternary Period is the current and most recent of the three periods of the Cenozoic Era. It is divided into two epochs: the Pleistocene and the Holocene (which began 11,700 years ago). The Quaternary is typically defined by the cyclic growth and decay of continental ice sheets driven by Milankovitch cycles and the associated climate and environmental changes that occurred. The last expansion of the polar ice sheets took place about 12,000 years ago.

The Quaternary is a period of the repeating glaciations, which are defined by the previously mentioned Milankovitch cycles. The angle of Earth’s axial tilt with respect to the orbital plane varies between 22.1 and 24.5 degrees over a cycle of about 41,000 years. The current tilt is 23.44 degrees, roughly halfway between its extreme values. Increased tilt increases the amplitude of the seasonal cycle, providing more solar radiation in each hemisphere’s summer and less in winter – in other words, climate at higher latitudes becomes warmer and stops glaciation. The tilt last reached its maximum 10,700 years ago and now is in the decreasing phase of its cycle and will reach its minimum in 9,800 years. The current trend of decreasing tilt will promote milder seasons, as well as an overall cooling trend. A new Ice Age is approaching.\nIn order to understand the impact of the glaciations, we should compare three regions at roughly the same latitude – China, North America, and Europe. Chinese flora is extremely rich, with million-year-old relics like Ginkgo, Magnolia, and Thujopsis. North America, too, has such ancient plants as Taxodium and Sequoiadendron. Europe, however, has essentially no ancient plant groups at all (except for a few in the Mediterranean). Why is it that the Ice Ages affected plants in China and North America so differently from those in Europe? The answer lies in geography. Glaciations affect European plant life more severely: during the last glaciation, most of Europe was buried under ice and it was very difficult for Europe’s plants to escape southwards, because they were blocked by the Alps and Mediterranean Sea, both of which extend generally from east to west. (The Mediterranean region was able to retain some ancient plants like Platanus and Olea). North America, especially it’s eastern coastal region, was usually free of snow, and its mountains run generally north-south, making it easier for plants to retreat southward, away from the encroaching glaciers. China, in contrast, was not covered by glaciers at all. It’s hard to imagine that before the Quaternary, Europe was home to gingkoes and beautiful Magnolias.\nQuaternary glaciations also obstructed humans from migrating into Europe, and repeatedly destroyed the populations that did settle there.

The Quaternary is the modern period, and it represents our current fauna and flora. However, periodic glaciations had a huge impact on the terrestrial biota, frequently destroying plant and animal species. After the last ice age, many large Pleistocene mammals such as saber-tooth cats, mammoths, and mastodons became extinct worldwide.
